Visit 1: Graphs & Charts

Math 100L Lesson 10 PDF

Bring your laptop computer to Visit #1.

Speaking Skill

Read the following information to your Speaking Partner:

When you explain how to do something or how to solve a problem, use words and expressions that show the time when each step is to be done. This is called “chronological order.” It is very important when learning math operations or programs such as Excel because there are steps that must be done before other steps. The following words are used often when explaining a process.

after

last

after that

next

afterward

now

before

then

finally

until

first

when

 

Discussion Questions

  1. How important are these words in explaining a process? Can you try to explain how to do something without using these words?
  2. Explain how to add 358 + 89 and see how many times you use the words above.
  3. Explain to your Speaking Partner how to create a spreadsheet document in Excel without showing the computer screen.
  4. Tell your Speaking Partner how you celebrate Christmas with your family. How often do you use the words listed above?
  5. Listen for the process words above as your speaking partner tells how he/she celebrates Christmas.

Graphs and Charts

This week you will be learning how to make a chart and a graph in Excel. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner.

Microsoft Excel makes it very easy to create a graph. All you have to do is put in the data and Excel creates the graph.

  • The first step is to put data into Excel. You have already put in information on a spreadsheet for a savings plan.

  • Highlight the data for the graph by clicking and dragging your mouse across it.

  • Click on the “Insert” tab at the top of the screen.

  • Locate the “Charts” section of the Insert tab. Several types of graphs are available.

  • Click on the type you want. For this class, choose the line graph.

  • Excel will then make a graph showing the data you chose.

  • To change the data selected, right-click on the chart and different choices will appear.

Discussion Questions

  1. Have you used Microsoft Excel to make a chart or graph before taking this class?
  2. Do you understand how to create a graph?
  3. Your portfolio assignment this week is to create a graph of a realistic savings plan for yourself for 20 years.
  4. Create a graph of a savings plan. Go through each step with your speaking partner.
  5. Can you think of other data that would be interesting to see in a graph?
  6. Create a graph for this information.

3/4 - 4/5x = 3/8y + 2
10m + 6x3 = 4(m3 + 54) - 5x2

Visit 2: Maps; Coordinates

Bring your scriptures to Speaking Partner visit #2

This week you are learning how to find locations on a map. Read the following information to your Speaking Partner.

Because letters and numbers go in definite orders, they are called “ordinates.” When they are used together to pinpoint an exact location, they are then called “coordinates.” The use of coordinates to find an exact location was introduced into mathematics centuries ago by a man named René Descartes. Now his method to specify locations is used widely throughout the world. Longitude and latitude are the two numbers that, when used together, can give us an exact location on the planet and form the basis for all ship and plane navigation.

Discussion Questions

  • Do you know how to find specific locations on the maps in your scriptures?
  • First you must find the index or gazetteer which comes before the map pages.
  • This lists the names of places found in the scriptures with a letter/number combination and a page number. It might be listed with the page number first (as in 12:D4) or second (as in B2:5).
  • With your Speaking Partner, find the following locations on the scripture maps: Alexandria in Egypt, Bethany, Great Pyramids, Indus River, and Mount Sinai.
  • Using coordinates is also valuable when reading charts and graphs. What are the approximate amounts represented by the dots in the graph below?

Pronunciation Practice

English pronunciation of the “r” sound

The “r” sound in English is a sound in which the mouth moves during pronunciation. Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following words. Then repeat the words.

read

run

real

risk

rip

rich

ready

room

right

repeat

Listen to your Speaking Partner say the following words when the “r” sound is not at the beginning of the word. Then repeat the words.

correct

try

short

turn

shirt

circle

four

warn

heart

third

Do the following activity with your Speaking Partner.

List as many cities or countries as you can that have the “r” sound. Examples: New York, Ireland.

Choose a place you would like to visit. Use some of the following phrases with the “r” sound to tell why you want to visit that place. First say each phrase and make sure you understand the meaning.

really beautiful

friendly people

lots of rain or rainbows

race tracks

research schools

culturally rich

rivers

rave reviews

a large range of foods

rat race

reptiles

retail stores

rifle ranges

rock climbing

rock ‘n’ roll bands
